page.description: Converts a date into a character value in the form 'MM/DD/YYYY'.
page.syntax: Formatted_Date as C = DTOC(D date[,C date_format[,L localized]]) or Formatted_Date as C = DTOC( Date_Time as T [, Format as C ] )

argument.name: Formatted_Date
argument.description: The Date_Value formatted into a character string.

argument.name: date
argument.description: A variable containing a date value or a character string containing a legitimate representation of a date value ( ISDATE (Date_Value) = .T.).

argument.name: Date_Time
argument.description: A variable containing a date time value.

argument.name: date_format
argument.description: Optional. Default = "MM/DD/YYYY". Refer to Predefined Date Formats.

page.discussion: DTOC() returns a character string in the specified Format for the specified Date or Date_Time value. DTOC() is useful for indexing a table when month order is more important than chronological date order (which orders first by year, then month, then day). If you have a multi-field index involving both date and character fields, use the CDATE() function if you want a chronological date order.
page.example: dim dd as D dd = date() ? dtoc(dd,"1-") = "01-06-2004" ? dtoc(dd,"4") = "January 6, 2004"
